docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Silent Struggle: A New Theory of Pregnancy'' (March 14): To describe pregnancy as a battle between mother and unborn child overlooks a simple fact: pregnancy, on balance, is good for women. The benefits of childbirth far outweigh the risks involved.
docs.abstract: Peter McFadden letter on March 14 article about pregnancy suggests that carrying baby has healthy benefits for women even after baby is born
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''Silent Struggle: A New Theory of Pregnancy'' (March 14): To describe pregnancy as a battle between mother and unborn child overlooks a simple fact: pregnancy, on balance, is good for women. The benefits of childbirth far...

docs.lead_paragraph: Legislation that would have required all hospitals, including Catholic facilities, to prescribe rape victims the morning-after pill was allowed to die yesterday. The Public Health Committee, which considered the bill 15 minutes before its deadline, ran out of time to act on a possible compromise that would have allowed Catholic hospitals to use private nurses to administer the pill. The medication helps prevent pregnancy if taken within 72 hours of intercourse. It is questionable whether the idea will be brought up as an amendment to another bill sometime before the legislative session ends in May. The state's four Catholic hospitals opposed the compromise, arguing it still interfered with the church's religious freedoms.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Morning-After Pill Measure Dies

docs.abstract: Connecticut legislation that would have required all hospitals, including Catholic facilities, to prescribe rape victims morning-after pill is allowed to die (S)
docs.snippet: Legislation that would have required all hospitals, including Catholic facilities, to prescribe rape victims the morning-after pill was allowed to die yesterday. The Public Health Committee, which considered the bill 15 minutes before its deadline,...

docs.lead_paragraph: An article in Science Times last Tuesday about recent research on pregnancy, suggesting that its dangers can be explained by a tug of war between mother and fetus over nutrients, referred incorrectly to one process in this conflict. Fetal cells called trophoblasts invade the maternal blood vessels to draw nutrients from the mother; the invaders are not fetal blood vessels.

docs.lead_paragraph: KeyCorp, Cleveland, consolidated its marketing communications assignments, with spending estimated at $35 million, and awarded them to Cramer-Krasselt, Chicago. The work had been divided between GSW Worldwide, Columbus, Ohio, and Northlich, Cincinnati. Dow Chemical, Midland, Mich., consolidated its advertising and marketing assignments, which had been divided among various agencies, and awarded them to agencies owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies, New York. Spending was estimated at $20 million to $30 million. The decision came after a review that was narrowed to the Interpublic agencies, led by Foote Cone & Belding and Golin/Harris, and agencies owned by the WPP Group.
docs.snippet: KeyCorp, Cleveland, consolidated its marketing communications assignments, with spending estimated at $35 million, and awarded them to Cramer-Krasselt, Chicago. The work had been divided between GSW Worldwide, Columbus, Ohio, and Northlich,...

docs.lead_paragraph: One day last October, Karyn, a 39-year-old executive, pulled her online dating profile off JDate and Match.com, two sites she had been using, along with an endless series of leads, tips and blind dates arranged by friends and colleagues, to search for a man she wanted to marry and raise a family with. At long last, after something like 100 dates in the past 10 years and several serious relationships, she had found the man she refers to, tongue only slightly in cheek, as ''the one.'' It all began last summer, when she broke off a relationship with a younger man who wasn't ready for children and got serious about the idea of conceiving on her own. She gathered information about fertility doctors and sperm banks. ''Then a childhood friend of mine was over,'' she told me. ''I pulled up the Web site of the only sperm bank that I know of that has adult photos. There happened to be one Jewish person. I pulled up the photo, and I looked at my friend, and I looked at his picture, and I said, 'Oh, my God.' I can't say love at first sight, because, you know. But he was the one.''
docs.abstract: Jennifer Egan article on growing trend toward single motherhood with women selecting what they hope will be good genetic material from profiles of sperm donors; while lesbian couples have long been conceiving with donor sperm, idea is relatively new for heterosexual women who are watching their biological clocks tick but not meeting men with whom they want to raise families; support group Single Mothers by Choice enrolled double number of new members in 2005 as it did 10 years ago and business is booming for sperm banks; experiences of several women described; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Tired of waiting for the right guy to come along, more and more women are just looking for the right sperm. But for a woman trying to have a child alone, choosing a donor is only the beginning.

docs.lead_paragraph: Jeremiah Clayton Jones discovered that his former fiancée was pregnant just three weeks before the baby was due, when an adoption-agency lawyer called and asked if he would consent to have his baby adopted. ''I said absolutely not,'' said Mr. Jones, a 23-year-old Arizona man who met his ex-fiancée at Pensacola Christian College in Florida. ''It was an awkward moment, hearing for the first time that I would be a father, and then right away being told, 'We want to take your kid away.' But I knew that if I was having a baby, I wanted that baby.''

headline.main: Unwed Fathers Fight for Babies Placed for Adoption by Mothers

docs.abstract: Unmarried father has no right under law in some states to withhold consent for adoption unless he has registered with putative father registry before adoption petition is filed; remains open question whether registries serve more to protect fathers' rights or to protect adoptive parents from biological fathers' claims; many men remain ignorant of registries and some women refuse to identify father to forestall interference; photo (L)
docs.snippet: At a time when one in three American babies is born to unwed parents, birth fathers' rights remain an unsettled area.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Chinatown businesswoman who calls herself Sister Ping was sentenced yesterday to 35 years in prison for running one of New York City's most lucrative immigrant smuggling rings and for financing the infamous voyage of the Golden Venture, the rusting freighter that ran aground off Queens in 1993 with nearly 300 starving immigrants in its fetid hold. Ten of the immigrants died after they leaped into chilly waves off the Rockaways in a final effort to reach American soil.

headline.main: Ringleader Gets 35-Year Term In Smuggling Of Immigrants

docs.abstract: Federal Judge Michael B Mukasey sentences Cheng Chui Ping to 35 years in prison for running one of New York City's most lucrative immigrant smuggling rings; Cheng financed 1993 voyage of freighter Golden Venture, which ran aground in Queens with nearly 300 immigrants aboard, 10 of whom died after leaping overboard to make land; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Sister Ping, whose given name is Cheng Chui Ping, ignored her lawyers' advice and delivered a meandering speech before she was sentenced.

docs.lead_paragraph: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about recent research on pregnancy, suggesting that its dangers can be explained by a tug of war between mother and fetus over nutrients, misstated the university affiliation of Kyle Summers, a biologist who praised the work. It is East Carolina University, not East Carolina State.

docs.lead_paragraph: 9:30 P.M. (5) THE LOOP -- Series premiere. A fun-loving recent college graduate, Sam (Bret Harrison), has become an airline executive in Chicago. He's constantly torn between his dronelike office existence and the party-all-the-time attitude of his roommates. And he's in unrequited love with one roommate, Piper (Amanda Loncar, above, with Mr. Harrison), a Catherine Zeta-Jones look-alike. This new sitcom likes to introduce its characters with on-screen descriptions. Mimi Rogers, for instance, who plays Meryl, a work colleague, is identified as ''Predator.'' The explanation for Sam's rowdy brother, Sully (Eric Christian Olsen), is ''Mom smoked grass during pregnancy.'' 6:30 P.M. (Sundance) THE GLASS MENAGERIE (1987). Joanne Woodward plays Amanda Wingfield, one of the great Tennessee Williams heroines. Karen Allen is her physically handicapped daughter, Laura. John Malkovich is Laura's brother, the Williams alter ego. And James Naughton, the two-time Tony Award winner (''Chicago'' and ''City of Angels''), is Laura's gentleman caller. Paul Newman, Ms. Woodward's husband of 48 years, directed. 8 P.M. (NBC) THE BIGGEST LOSER: SPECIAL EDITION -- Either the Navy wives or the Marine Corps wives will win this weight-loss competition tonight when both teams face the final weigh-in. Before that, the slimed-down Navy wives reunite with their husbands, who have been at sea for six months. 8 P.M. (Food) CHEFOGRAPHY: GIADA DE LAURENTIIS -- How does the Italian-born, movie-star-beautiful granddaughter of a legendary film producer become a television chef? Ms. DeLaurentiis (right), whose grandfather is Dino, grew up in Beverly Hills, majored in anthropology at U.C.L.A., suffered at the Cordon Bleu school in Paris, took a job at Spago, went into catering and made a splash in a magazine article. 9 P.M. (5) AMERICAN IDOL -- The competition is down to 12 finalists, and one of them will be eliminated on this results show. Chances are it won't be Lisa Tucker or Mandisa. 9 P.M. (9) VERONICA MARS -- Closeted gay teenagers panic when someone hacks into their online bulletin board. The blackmailer threatens to tell all unless they pay $5,000 each. It's just another day in wealthy Neptune Beach, and Veronica (Kristen Bell, left), possibly the only detective on television who looks like the head cheerleader at a special school for blondes, will try to help. ANITA GATES
